etymology.value: From Proto-Italic *wetus, from Proto-Indo-European *wet- (“year”). Cognate with Ancient Greek ἔτος (étos, “year”), Sanskrit वत्सर (vatsara, “year”), Old Church Slavonic вѣтъ (větŭ, “year”), Lithuanian vẽtušas (“old, worn-out”).

usage_notes.explanation: 'Vetus' is a Latin adjective used to describe something that is old in age or has existed for a long time. It is a one-termination adjective, meaning its nominative singular form is the same for masculine, feminine, and neuter genders. It is often contrasted with 'novus' (new).

level_frequency.frequency_comment: Common in Latin literature, especially historical texts.

example_sentences.translation: The temple was old. (その神殿は古かった。)
It is an old proverb. (それは古い諺だ。)
Old wine is good. (古いワインは良い。)
